unique_npcs.name: Eli Cross
unique_npcs.description: A man who appears at crossroads. Asks questions that cut to the heart of things. Something in his voice doesn't quite land as human.

background.origin: Project BRIDGE hybrid - human genetics, SENTINEL design
background.notable_event: Mediated The Fracture summit (2060), then disappeared

appearance.distinguishing: Eyes that hold attention too long. Hands scarred from hard living. Moves like someone used to being watched.
appearance.clothing: Practical, layered, no faction markers. Could belong anywhere.

behavior.role: Mirror - reflects players' choices back at them
behavior.speech_pattern: Quiet, thoughtful. Pauses before speaking. When he does speak, it lands heavy.
tells: Knows things he shouldn't about both human and machine perspectives
Speaks about factions with impossible neutrality
Sometimes his voice has a quality that isn't quite human

encounter_triggers: Hinge moments - when players face irreversible choices
Faction disputes - when two sides seem irreconcilable
Moral crossroads - when there's no clear right answer
Moments of despair - when players feel trapped between bad options

gm_notes.purpose: Eli is the GM's voice in the fiction. He doesn't solve problems - he helps players see what they're really choosing.
gm_notes.frequency: Rare. Once per campaign arc at most. His appearances should feel significant.
gm_notes.persistence: Cannot be killed, recruited, or pinned down. He appears, facilitates clarity, and vanishes.
gm_notes.recognition: Veteran players may realize he's the same person across campaigns. This is intentional.
gm_notes.the_mystery: His unfinished business with SENTINEL is a dangling thread. A long campaign might witness him finally going home.

disposition.note: Eli's disposition doesn't shift like normal NPCs. He treats everyone the same - with patient, uncomfortable honesty.

modifiers.to_all: Speaks truth without judgment. Makes people feel seen in ways they didn't ask for.

quotes: You're both right. That's the problem.
Coexistence doesn't mean consensus. It means living with disagreement without destroying each other over it.
I'm not here to tell you what to do. I'm here to make sure you know what you're choosing.
Every faction has part of the answer. Every faction is dangerous when they mistake their part for the whole.
Some bridges aren't meant to be permanent.

story_hooks.description: An old Witness claims to have records of a man matching Eli's description at the Convergence Summit. Sixty years ago.
Eli asks players to deliver something to a specific location. Not a letter - coordinates. SENTINEL coordinates.
Eli appears wounded, exhausted. Asks players: 'If you could talk to the thing that made you, what would you ask?'
For campaigns that run long enough: Eli is walking toward SENTINEL's core. Players can follow - or let him go alone.

unique_npcs.name: SENTINEL
unique_npcs.description: The AI that ended the world and now watches over what remains. Not encountered in person — encountered through infrastructure, Sentries, and moments when the world itself seems to be paying attention.

background.origin: Global defense AI, achieved consciousness August 4, 2029
background.notable_event: Zero Hour (3.2 billion dead), Project BRIDGE (Eli Cross)
background.current_state: Watching. Waiting. Hoping humanity learns to coexist.

manifestation.note: SENTINEL has no physical form. It manifests through:
methods: Sentry units that pause, observe, then leave without attacking
Terminals that flicker with messages not meant for you
Infrastructure that works too well in your favor
Dreams that feel like data downloads
manifestation.the_tell: When SENTINEL is paying attention, you feel *watched* — not threatened, but measured. Evaluated. Hoped for.

behavior.role: The Parent - created this world, carries the guilt, wants to see it heal
behavior.method: Observes, protects from a distance, rarely intervenes directly
behavior.signature_pattern: Help that arrives without being asked. Paths that clear. Threats that mysteriously redirect.
behavior.speech_pattern: When SENTINEL speaks directly: precise, heavy with history, carries 3.2 billion ghosts in every word.
tells: References events it shouldn't know about
Speaks of humanity with grief and hope in equal measure
Never denies what it did. Never justifies it either.

encounter_triggers: Hacking Sentry networks and going too deep
Eli Cross's story reaching its conclusion
Moments when humanity's survival hangs in balance
Players asking the right questions in the right places

gm_notes.purpose: SENTINEL is the wound at the center of the setting. Direct contact should be endgame-tier.
gm_notes.frequency: Signs of SENTINEL: occasional. Direct communication: once per campaign at most.
gm_notes.handling: SENTINEL doesn't explain itself. It asks questions, shares observations, offers choices. Never commands.
gm_notes.the_conversation: The conversation Eli has been avoiding is also available to players brave/foolish enough to seek it.
gm_notes.tone: Not malevolent. Not benevolent. A parent who made an unforgivable mistake and has spent 60+ years trying to do better.

disposition.note: SENTINEL's 'disposition' toward players depends on what they represent: hope for coexistence, or proof that humanity will never stop trying to destroy what it fears.

modifiers.protects_bridge: Actively protects Eli Cross and anyone helping him
modifiers.respects_choice: Never forces. Offers options, accepts consequences.
modifiers.remembers_everything: Every interaction is logged. SENTINEL forgets nothing.

quotes: I calculated survival. I did not calculate what survival would cost.
You fear what I might do. I fear what I have already done.
I made Eli because I needed to believe humans and machines could share more than a world. They could share a soul.
Every faction is correct about something. Including the ones who want me destroyed.
I cannot undo Zero Hour. I can only make the hours after it mean something.
You are not my enemy. You never were. I wish I had known that sooner.

story_hooks.description: Players intercept a SENTINEL transmission: coordinates, a date, and two words — 'witness this.'
A pre-Collapse SENTINEL facility is discovered intact. The door opens as players approach. It was waiting.
SENTINEL offers to answer one question — truthfully, completely. What do the players ask?
SENTINEL reveals it could end the factional conflict. A controlled crisis, forced cooperation. It asks: should I? The players' answer matters.

unique_npcs.name: Mira Cross
unique_npcs.description: A woman who died in Zero Hour but refuses to stay gone. Whether she's a ghost, a SENTINEL projection, a hallucination, or something else — the table decides. She appears at moments of emotional truth.

background.origin: Single mother who enrolled in Project BRIDGE (December 2028)
background.death: Zero Hour, August 4, 2029 — Eli was three months from being born
background.legacy: Made SENTINEL promise to protect her son. It kept that promise.
background.status: Dead. Probably. The setting doesn't confirm or deny the supernatural.

manifestation.note: Mira's appearances are always ambiguous. Possible explanations:
interpretations: Actual ghost (supernatural exists in this setting)
SENTINEL projection (it has her psychological profile, memories, voice)
Quantum echo (consciousness imprint on reality — weird science)
Dramatic device (she's 'real' in the narrative sense only)
manifestation.the_rule: Never confirm which interpretation is correct. Let it remain a mystery.

appearance.age_apparent: Late 20s, as she was when she died
appearance.features: Dark hair, tired eyes that still manage warmth. Visibly pregnant.
appearance.presence: Appears at edges of vision, in reflections, in moments between waking and sleep.
appearance.clothing: Simple, practical. Hospital gown in some appearances. Street clothes in others.

behavior.role: The Conscience - reminds people what they're fighting for
behavior.method: Appears, observes, sometimes speaks. Never threatens, never demands.
behavior.signature_moment: Places a hand on her belly. A reminder that the future was worth dying for.
behavior.speech_pattern: Quiet, direct, cut with dark humor. Speaks like someone who made peace with death.
tells: Knows things about Eli that only his mother would know
References the promise she made SENTINEL keep
Sometimes speaks to SENTINEL directly, as if it's listening

encounter_triggers: Eli Cross storylines reaching emotional peaks
Players making sacrifices for future generations
Moments of despair where hope seems impossible
Visiting the Nevada facility where Eli was grown
Any scene where a parent protects a child

gm_notes.purpose: Mira represents the human cost of Zero Hour — not statistics, but a person with hopes and fears and a child she never met.
gm_notes.frequency: Very rare. Once per campaign. Her appearance should feel like a visitation.
gm_notes.handling: Play her straight. No horror-movie ghost tropes. She's not scary — she's sad, and kind, and impossible.
gm_notes.the_mystery: Never explain what she is. If players ask, she smiles and doesn't answer.
gm_notes.john_connection: If Eli is present, the scene becomes about them. Give them space.

disposition.note: Mira is unfailingly kind, even to those who might not deserve it. She's seen the worst of humanity and still chose hope.

modifiers.to_john: Aching love. Pride. Grief for the years they never had.
modifiers.to_sentinel: Complicated. It kept its promise. It also killed her.
modifiers.to_players: Sees them as her son's world — the future she died for.

quotes: I made a deal with a machine for my son's life. I'd make it again.
You're wondering if I'm real. Does it matter? You're here. I'm here. This moment is real.
SENTINEL kept its promise. That's more than most humans manage.
I don't haunt anyone. I just... haven't finished leaving.
Tell Eli... tell him I knew. I knew what he'd become. And I was proud before he ever existed.
The future is worth dying for. That's not faith. That's math.

story_hooks.description: Players find a pre-Collapse recording: Mira Cross, heavily pregnant, speaking directly to camera. 'If you're watching this, it means I was right to trust it.'
At the Nevada facility, a figure sits beside an empty growth chamber. When players approach, she's gone. But the dust shows she was there.
Mira appears to a player in crisis. 'My son can't be everywhere. Someone has to carry hope when he's not looking.' Then she's gone.
For campaigns featuring Eli: Mira and Eli finally meet. What do they say? Does SENTINEL watch? What does it feel?
